title: mg.metric geometry - Conv A = Dual B
body: I have two cones $A$ and $B$ in a Euclidean space. I want to show that $\mathrm{Conv}\,A=\mathrm{Dual}\,B$ ; that is, $a\in\mathrm{Conv}\,A$ if and only if $\langle a,b\rangle\ge 0$ for any $b\in B$ . The inclusion $\mathrm{Conv}\,A\subset \mathrm{Dual}\, B$ (or equivalently $\mathrm{Dual}\,A\supset \mathrm{Conv}\,B$ ) is easy --- one has to check $\langle a,b\rangle\ge 0$ for pairs $a\in A$ and $b\in B$ . It remains to show the opposite inclusion $\mathrm{Conv}\,A\supset \mathrm{Dual}\,B$ . I see that in principle it can be done by calculations. Do you know tricks that help to prove the opposite inclusion $\mathrm{Conv}\,A\supset \mathrm{Dual}\,B$ ? Is there software that can help? The cones $A$ and $B$ are very concrete; they are given by few algebraic identities and inequalities in $\mathbb R^{10}$ . (In principle I could describe the sets of vectors here, but I do not think it might help.) mg.metric-geometry convex-geometry convex-optimization convex-analysis Share Cite Improve this question Follow asked Jun 19, 2020 at 19:30 Anton Petrunin 47.1k 17 17 gold badges 148 148 silver badges 315 315 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 5 1 $\begingroup$ I assume that $\operatorname{Conv} A$ denotes the convex hull of $A$? But why do you need to take the convex hull of a cone, given that a cone is already convex? $\endgroup$ Jochen Glueck –  Jochen Glueck 2020-06-19 21:27:10 +00:00 Commented Jun 19, 2020 at 21:27 1 $\begingroup$ @JochenGlueck I did not say that cones are convex (in fact they are not). $\endgroup$ Anton Petrunin –  Anton Petrunin 2020-06-20 03:51:01 +00:00 Commented Jun 20, 2020 at 3:51 $\begingroup$ Thank you very much for your response! Hmm, may I suggest to include a definition of your usage of the word cone in the question? (I just browsed half a dozen books about ordered vector spaces; many of them define a cone indeed to be always convex, while some others do not - and there also seem to be some further differences between the various definitions of a cone in the literature). $\endgroup$ Jochen Glueck –  Jochen Glueck 2020-06-20 12:49:59 +00:00 Commented Jun 20, 2020 at 12:49 $\begingroup$ @JochenGlueck a set $X$ is a cone if $v\in X$ implies that $\lambda{\cdot}v\in X$ for any $\lambda\ge0$. $\endgroup$ Anton Petrunin –  Anton Petrunin 2020-06-20 19:08:33 +00:00 Commented Jun 20, 2020 at 19:08 $\begingroup$ Thank you very much. $\endgroup$ Jochen Glueck –  Jochen Glueck 2020-06-20 20:04:57 +00:00 Commented Jun 20, 2020 at 20:04 Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
